newsitem.title: BELARUS: Council of Europe official voices concern in Belarus.
newsitem.headline: Council of Europe official voices concern in Belarus.

text.p: Council of Europe official Leni Fischer warned President Alexander Lukashenko on Wednesday that his plans to increase his own powers might divide the former Soviet republic of Belarus.
And Parliamentary Speaker Semyon Sharetsky told Fischer that violence might break out during pro- and anti-Lukashenko rallies this weekend.
Fischer, head of the Council of Europe's parliamentary assembly, was in Belarus to discuss its application to join the 39-nation body which promotes democracy and human rights.
She told parliament, at loggerheads with Lukashenko over a referendum to extend his term, that there was "serious concern" in the Council at the constitutional crisis.
"I call on the leadership of your country to try again to find a compromise and not to confuse the nation," she said.
"Any attempt to bypass a parliament should be avoided because this can split a nation. I hope that your constitution will be faithfully respected and followed," Fischer said.
Lukashenko has served half the five-year term he is allowed by the constitution but is seeking another five years without elections in a referendum he wants to hold on November 7.
The 41-year-old leader was in Moscow on Wednesday, meeting President Boris Yeltsin and discussing integration with Russia.
"The presidents said they favoured a consolidation of society on the basis of compromise, corresponding to the demands of a legitimate, democratic path of development," Yeltsin's press service said.
Lukashenko, elected on a platform of fighting corruption and re-building ties with Russia, has drawn criticism from parliament and nationalists for signing a pact to create a "community" with Russia.
Up to 200 people were given short jail terms after mass rallies last spring led to clashes with police.
Another major demonstration is expected on Saturday to coincide with an "All-Belarus" congress being held by Lukashenko to garner support for his referendum.
Speaker Sharetsky, the country's second highest political figure, met Fischer and told her Lukashenko was running a dictatorship.
"I await with fear the events of October 18 and 19. Yesterday my deputy said he expected bloodshed," he said.
Deputies, who according to the constitution must approve the date of any referendum, have twice rejected Lukashenko's plan to hold the vote on a new draft constitution on November 7.

Lukashenko is also seeking authority to appoint one-third of the members of a new upper house of parliament. Deputies have instead called a vote for November 24 -- on a constitution abolishing the post of president.
